dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: kneels toward the man sprawled on his stomach, legs apart, arms above his head. Sam feels inside and under the chest for a heartbeat, finds none. He stares a long moment at the fixed. profile, graven against the pavement, notices the dark blotch at the back of the head. Tentatively he reaches out, lets his fingertips touch the matted hair. He brings his hand back and in the faint glow of the nearest street lamp considers the brown-red smear. Sam hurries to the patrol car, ANGLE WIDENING,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies on top the bed. His eyes are wide open, fixed in a study of the ceiling. Sweat runs off his big body. Except for a pair of rumpled shorts he is naked. The cheap alarm clock on the night table near his head ticks noisily. The man is BILL GILLESPIE, new chief of police of Wells. The telephone rings. He reaches for it swiftly. None of this leisured stuff for Bill Gillespie. Ring - grab.

dialogues.text: (cool, shaking his head} I'm sending it in. Personally!

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (almost shouting it) Lock him up, Wood! Withholding evidence. Lock him up with Oberst, They make a sweet pair! Gillespie goes into his office and slams his door. At onc the other officers break into derisive, delighted laughte (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sam even claps a congratulatory hand on Tibbs! ‘shoulder he leads him off toward the cells, CAMERA MOVING with the two men,

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Nobody threw your brains to the hogs, Virgil, that's for damn sure}

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE CELLBLOCK
dialogues.text: coming down the corridor past a row of unoccupied cells, Sam stops in front of the one cell which is occupied. Harvey Oberst is slumped disconsolately on one of two cots, but when he sees Sam unlocking the bars and bringin in a Negro as his cellmate, he jumps to his feet,

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: Man, not in here: Put him somewheres else! Sam ignores the protest, closes Tibbs inside with Oberst, goes off down the corridor even as Oberst calls after him pleading.

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: You hear me? How come in here’ Hey! But the clanging of a distant door mari:s Sam's response, Now the silence comes down over the cell block,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching Tibbs. Tibbs pays no attention to the white man, Tibbs settles on his own bunk, leans his head against the wall, closes his eyes, not in sleep, but in thought, Ober continues to glare at him,

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: What you doin! wearin! white man's clothes? Tibbs opens his eyes, considers the hostile young man in torn shirt and tattered blue jeans.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: I bought them from a white man, Oberst advances on him, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He flashes

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: (a long beat) Who you thiak you are, boy?

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: (quietly) All you got,

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: (a sudden shout) I don't need yout

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Look, Harv... his police badge. Oberst stares at it, frowns,

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: I'm on your side,

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: (reading the badge number) Powleece, Philadelphia. You? You're a - cop? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 9/8/56 43,

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tibbs nods.

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: Yeah? So how come they locked you up? How come they'd go lock up @ cop?

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Who says they locked me up? How come - with all these empty cells - they put me in with you? Dig? Oberst stares at him another moment, then turns, grabs at the bars.

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: (an outburst) Look, I already told 'em! I see this fella lyin' on the street there - this wallet next to him ~ I mean, boy, I come into this world outa luck. Here's the first good thing to come my way. I pick it up. But when I see whose wallet it is, I mean I start to sweat! Oberst turns back from the bars,

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: (continuing) But I heard about this new Chie?, this Gillespie - got no more smile 'n a turnip, so I cut across the fields and got myself far as the river 'fore them dogs treed me.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: When did you find the wallet? What time?

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: I ain't got no watch. But I know it was after two from the court house clock,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm interested in eleven to two. Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: Shootin! pool - Larry's Lounge. Got there ‘bout ten. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 9/8/66 103

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: And left - when?

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: Not 'til closin' - after one.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Witnesses who can speak for you?

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: Packy - Bert - Les. Tibbs nods, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Ever been in trouble with the police before? Oberst doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: (continuing) T can ask at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: (finally) Well, they brought me in one time 'count of Delores Purdy.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: On what charge?

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: This Delores ~ she's real proud of what nature done ror her, y' know? We're on a date, up to Clarke's Point. Anyway, she asks me - you see - she asks me ~ don't I think she gota classy build an' I say sure and she starts to show me - I didn't do nothin' wrong. I just - didn't stop her from tryin' to prove her point. Then this cop ‘Sam Wood - he comes outa the bush and hauls me in.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Apparently, they let you go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: Tole me not to mess with her no more. She lives over on Third, ‘bout a block from me. Walks around the house in the altogether. An' after dark - with the lights on! Well, somebody sure oughta make her stop doin' that! Tibbs smiles wryly, knowing he is hearing the truth. He gets off the bunk. TIBBS ° Let me see your hands. Harvey looks puzzled, tut holds them out. Tibbs soes over them carefully, front and back.

dialogues.speaker: OBERST
dialogues.text: What you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Hold still. Hold still. Tibbs takes a file from his pocket, digs under one of the young man's nails, examines the scraping carefully. Suddenly he smiles at Oberst, a wide, bright smile full o confidence, then turns, discovers that Gillespie and Wood are Standing there, outside, in the corridor, watching.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (quiet now and calm) Give him the waiver, Wood - for false arrest. Sam passes it through.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: And a pen!

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Forget it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign! Tibbs shrugs, signs, hands paper and pen back to Sam, GILLES PIz Let him out, Wood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 «CONTINUED: (5} Wood opens the cell door and Tiots comes out with his , Wood locks Oberst in - by himself now,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (to Tibbs) You can catch the twelve-ten, Oh, and on your way you just go ahead and mail in that neat little parcel of yours to the FBI, With Tibbs, they start away down the corridor, Oberst loo after them plaintively,

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: as they head out toward the muster room, TIBsS (to Gillespie) I've asked them to send the results to you. Meanwhile, it might not be a bad idea if youtd release Harvey Oberst, His only mistake was taking a wallet fron where somebody deliberately planted it, At the time of the murder, he was somewhere else - and I think he can prove that, They leave the cell corridor,

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE RECEPTION AREA
dialogues.text: as Tibbs, Gillespie and Sam come out of the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Sure, I forgot, You're that city-boy - bright as a bird and twice as proud - who checks the brain with a thermometer, You probably know the exact time Colbert was killed,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 12:30 - while Harvey was still shooting pool, There's cue chalk under his nails - not dried blood, Harvey never camé near the actual scene of the crime. Gillespie blows out his breath, (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REV. 9/16/06 Aq, 105 106 107 CONTINUED ;

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Thank the Lord I don't live in Philadelphiat Wouldn'+ thet be a sad come~-up? Tibbs picks up his suitcase, moves toward the front door, When he reaches it, he looks back at Gillespie,

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Colbert was killed somewhere else, then moved to Main dtreet - to the place where Wood - and Harvey - found him,

dialogues.text: reacting to this bombshell,

dialogues.speaker: TISBS
dialogues.text: moves to the door, Goodbye, Chie?r, Tibbs goes out, closing the door after nix Nobody moves for what seems to be an eternity - until Gillespie tums toward nis officers,

dialogues.text: Aren't you supposed to be off- duty at eight?

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Only five after, sir, And I don't want to miss nothin', I mean, I want to do what I can, case you need me,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (chiming in) That's it, Chief,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (a low sigh) Courtney! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Yes, sir,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Change the charge to theft,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (reacting) Harv? From murder - to theft?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: We got anybody else locked up back there?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, sir,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Then do what I tell yout Gillespie slams his office door, George throws up his hands, Then the switchboard lights up. George takes the incoming call.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Police Department, Yes, he's here, Hold on, sir,., George rings Gillespie's office,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Mayor on the line, Chief, He closes the switch, looks up at the wall clock,

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Half a buck says fifteen seconds,

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Ten! They watch the second’ hand sweep around, It has passed eight seconds when Gillespie's door flies open and the Texan comes out,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) I'll-be with the Mayor, He goes out, Ten seconds have elapsed, George fishes out a half-dollar, lobs it across to Sam who catches it, cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE STREET
dialogues.text: swings out of the police parking area, sli:ies into early morning traffic.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Gillespie emerges from his police car and enters the show

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA TRACKS Gillespie across the showroom toward a enclosed, partitioned office. Inside the office we see MA WEBB SCHUBERT. Mrs. Leslie Colbert is with him. Gillespie enters the office and interrupts them in mid-confrontatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Gillespie enters,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (a nod to Mrs. Colbert, then to the Mayor ) Morning, Mayor. The Mayor looks from Mrs. Colbert to Gillespie glumly.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Hardly a good one, Chief, What's this Mrs. Colbert's telling me about a - a cover-up arrest? Gillespie levels a long look at the woman.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: I dropped the charge, Mrs. Colbect. (a beat) Insufficient evidence.

dialogues.speaker: . MAYOR
dialogues.text: (vastly relieved) I told you he was nobody's man! That's why we reached into Texas to find him!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLBERT
dialogues.text: (a long beat) I never knew much about - my husband's work... but I always knew - what mattered to him. Building this factory - here - in this town - that mattered. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: 118A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MRS, COLBERT (cont'd) (another beat) I'm going to see it gets done. But only on one condition!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Colbert, I'm grateful. Believe me - real grateful! I mean, I wouldn't blame you if you just packed wp all those engineers and blueprints and took 'em someplace else. Wouldn't blame you a bit!

dialogues.speaker: MRS, COLBERT
dialogues.text: (too quietly) That's what Mr. Endicott is counting on, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Well, now you have to try to understand how a man like Endicott looks at these things.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, but I do! (a beat, then her eyes on Gillespie) I came by to - to make it as clear as I possibly can - I don't want that Negro officer taken off this case!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: (astonished, turning to Gillespie) Negro - officer?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: From Philadelphia. Just - passing through.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. COLBERT
dialogues.text: If it weren't for him, your impartial Chief of Police would still have the wrong person behind bars. (a beat) I said I had a condition. I want that officer given a free hand. I want the guilty parties arrested - no matter who they are! (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 118A CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MRS. COLBERT (cont'd) (a final beat) Otherwise, I'll do exactly what you say you wouldn't blame me for doing - I'll pack up my husband's engineers and... (an inditement) «.- leave you to yourselves! She turns, goes out, the Mayor and Gillespie looking afte her.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: (finaily) I want to see you come through this! You hear?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Even if it turns out Endicott's got a toe in the trough?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: (a long beat) Even hat. (another deat) . But do it fast. Now what about this Negro officer? She seems to have a lot of confidence in him.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Some kind of - homicide expert - so he says. But I don't need him!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: You mean, you don't want him! But you do need him! (a. beat) Suppose he turns up the killer. He has no police power here. He'll have to hand him over on a platter. Right? And if he fails, you're off the hook, It was Mrs. Colbert's idea in the first place, see what I mean? It works all the way around, for all of us. Gillespie takes a deep breath, goes out. cut To:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE TRAIN STATION
dialogues.text: as he steps onto the train platform. Aside from a white baggage supervisor in a worn uniform no one else is on th platform, The supervisor is checking a shipment.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Is there a place around here I can get something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: BAGGAGE MASTER
dialogues.text: Well - there's Mary's - 'cross town, TISbS {a beat) Thanks, He starts away,

dialogues.speaker: BAGGAGE MASTER
dialogues.text: Boy! Machine in the waiting room - candy and peanut bars,

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Thank you, {a faint smile) Anmway. Tibbs moves away, CAMERA MOVING with him until he comes t the same door through which only a few hours earlier San Wood had hustled him. Tibbs puts down his suitcase and settles himself on a baggage wagon, He loosens his tie, d covers Gillespie coming dowa the platform toward him,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON TIBRBS ‘ reacting.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: coming closer,

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS AND GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: as the Chief stops near Tibbs,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: This train - any reason you got to catch it today? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 CONT TINUED ;

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Lots of reasons,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Guess I have been pretty rough,

dialogues.speaker: TIBES
dialogues.text: That's not one of them,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: If I asked you to stay a while, what would you say?

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: (almost smiling) No,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Be a world of satisfaction in norsewhinping you, Virgil!

dialogues.speaker: TIBRS
dialogues.text: My father used to say that, Even Go it - now and then,

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Not enough to suit met Gillespie pulls out a thin cigar, lights it, blows out sm

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: This town needs a factory,., Mister Colbert - he came down from Chicago to build one, A lot of people are for that, But a lot are against it, too, I've heard it told he'd be hiring as many as a thousand men *- half of ‘em colored, Know what that could mean, Virgil?

dialogues.speaker: TIBES
dialogues.text: It probably got him killed.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: That's what-Mrs. Colbert claims, She wants us to catch her a killer. No killer, no factory, that's abtut the size of it, It means joos for colored, you follow me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It; going home: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: But they're

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trying to m me bes you? That what you're after?

dialogues.speaker: TIBES
dialogues.text: (fiercely) Chief, I'm up to here with your towns

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (a beat) Now, voy, for once I'm going to hold my cemper} I'm telling you, you're staying: You're going to stay right here and help me beat this killing if I have to call your Chief back and remind hin what he ordered you to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tibbs reacts and Gilles: jie sees that Tibbs realizes this stratagem would indeed + ian

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: But I wontt have to do that because you're just’ so damned smart, sO much brighter than all the rest of us poor stupid white men, you're going to stay just to show us! Your head's so big you could never live with yourself unless you put us all to shane, Virgil, you going to pass up a chance like that?

dialogues.speaker: TIBES
dialogues.text: You make it very tempting. The two men stare at each other a long moment, their face hard and unfricadlir, Then dillespie turns, starts back a the platform, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Tibbs! feet enter SHOT, Tibbs kneels into SHOT, Sam Wood kneels also as CAMERA LOWERS TO HOLD the men in a TWO SHO (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Tibbs is examining the pavement around the chalk outline, the t.g. we can see the BLUR of the crowd pressing around watening,

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: I hear you right, Virgil, back at the station? You told the Chief Mister Colbert wasn't killed here? Tibbs runs his palm across the surface of the pavement,

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: (absently) That's right.

dialogues.text: Well, now, Virgil, I'm not a fella who's too proud to borrow milk, Itd be obliged you was to tell me how you figured that. Tibbs concentrates on the chalk outline,

dialogues.text: From the photographs you showed me, Now itm sure, -

dialogues.text: When a man dics, blood pressure falls to zero, Bleeding stops, In short, Mister Wood, dead bodies don't bleed,

dialogues.text: Main and Jacksen ~ that way - Walkin' distance ... Mind tellin'me what that's for?

dialogues.text: (baffled) Weather reports? Tibbs ducks under the barricade, moves swiftly toward the The baffled Sam looks up at the sky, as though expecting answer to the crime revealed there in the clouds.

dialogues.text: boils out of the door marked POLICE, CAMERA PANNING him a the corner of the building, then up the street to doors m He disappears inside. .

dialogues.speaker: INT, COUNCIL ROOM
dialogues.text: stop talking as Gillespie comes in, closes the door after one of the five council members are in shirt sleeves, jac backs of their chairs. One man - ERIC ENDICOTT - has kept jacket on, Fans emplaced along the table create a slight At the head of the table sits Schubert, the Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Boys asked me to cail you over ... He motions to an empty chair next to him. Gillespie igner gesture, remains standing, (Continued)  REV. 132 133

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: . try and clear the air. One of the men - WATKINS ~- leans demandingly toward Gillespie.

dialogues.speaker: WATKINS
dialogues.text: Just two things: What's bein! done? An' what's goin' on?

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: He lights one of the long thin cigars he carries in his breast pocket. He blows out smoke, watches the fan catch and twirl it around. Gillespie makes no attempt to hide his personal distaste for the Councilmen.

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: Isn't that one and the same question?

dialogues.speaker: WATKINS
dialogues.text: I mean, we wanta know what's bein! done to clear up the killin'. Aud we wanta know what's this about a nigger cop. Don't tell me that's one and the same question!

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: (a beat) Gillespie wasn't in favor of him - I insisted. There is a horrendous, judgmental silence.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: I insisted because Mrs. Colbert asked me to! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Some of the men react - this puts things in a different light, A second councilman - DENNIS - instantly sides wit the Mayor,

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS
dialogues.text: I say Webb done right, I say - keep her happy, Was her husband got killed, She wants a chimpanzee to investigate, I say we put a chimpanzee on the job}

dialogues.speaker: SHUIE
dialogues.text: (a third Councilman) I'il buy that!

dialogues.speaker: WATKINS
dialogues.text: Not me} That buck runnint loose, askin' questions of folks like he thinks he is somebody, You know what's goin' to happen? He'!1l get himself killed. You watch ant sce he don'tt

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: I'm aware of the risk, Tom, But, like it or not, we're stuck with him

dialogues.speaker: WATKINS
dialogues.text: (deprecating) Not if our Chief here was on the ball! What about it, Chief? You got the killer in your front sights?

dialogues.speaker: GILLESPIE
dialogues.text: (too defensively) I've got my irons out, don't worry!

dialogues.speaker: WATKINS
dialogues.text: (pressing) Ever investigate a killin' before, Mister Gillespie?

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Tom, climb off Gillespie's back now! You know damn well we didn't hire him off a homicide squad!

dialogues.speaker: WATKINS

dialogues.speaker: PURDY
dialogues.text: (to Ralph, slowly building} You turned my little girl into a field slut! He utters a low curse, swings the shotgun toward Ralph. Ralph fires defensively, the bullet striking Purdy in the stomach and crumpling him even as one of his own barrels blasts the sidewalk near Ralph's feet. Tibbs moves in- stantaneously, his knee coming up, his arm down, as he locks Ralph's gun hand painfully in a grip, forces him to drop the gun. Delores is on her knees alongside her father, holding his head and crying.

dialogues.speaker: DELORES
dialogues.text: Pal Pal The other whites seem utterly lost, all the fight out of them. Tibbs, meantime, has scooped up Ralph's revolver. There. is something in the way Tibbs holds the weapon tha makes its own statement of quiet authority. Mama Caleba stands, watching, in the doorway of her store.

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP
dialogues.text: as Mama in the b.g. re-enters her store. Among the group, nobody speaks, Only the sobbing of Delores is heard.

dialogues.text: takes the keys, selects one, hands the cluster back to Tibbs through the bars, one key up. Tibbs unlocks the gate, swings it open. But Sam lingers inside.

dialogues.speaker: TIBBS
dialogues.text: Go home, Sam. Shower... sleep... wake up... eat a steak... come back tonight - for your regular tour.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: He can't believe it.
